At first, I assumed it was the usual resistances / sa·πÖkhƒÅras. For a decade, I‚Äôve known it‚Äôs a neurological syndrome that many have (R.L.S.) and although it affects other parts of life, e.g., sleep, it‚Äôs never so intense as on retreat in the evening. As I calm and cleanse, it actually gets worse, even on longer retreats. If I don‚Äôt focus on exhaling calm and mettƒÅ, I would drive my neighbors crazy, twitching and squirming like a bored 4 year-old. But I‚Äôm not bored and I want to hear the teachings. The level of controlling the legs necessarily, even with calming, creates sometimes a kind of negative pƒ´ti‚Äîthunderbolts in the body with no delight or rapture! I intuit an ancient root to it but, what to do? Alternative and western guidance have not helped much. From your vast experience of squirming mediators, any advice? When I go inward, I don't feel or experience brightness. Instead it/I feel heavy. How can I get to that brightness?
When one is caught in depression or negativity, how can one brighten or uplift the mind?
Would you be willing to share memories of Ajahn Chah?

annotations.text: When asked about the core essence of the Buddha's teachings, Ajahn Chah replies, "Is this a big stick or a little stick?"
Ajahn Chah pretends to forget simple questions in order to embarass his translator.
Ajahn Pasanno writes to his family that he's staying in Thailand because Ajahn Chah is peaceful, solid, clear, and unshakeable in the midst of all that's going on around him.

excerpts.text: What's your opinion of the secular mindfulness movement (MBSR and its associated programs)? Can mindfulness serve a useful function for people without the rest of the Dhamma?

annotations.text: NibbƒÅna is not a thing.

excerpts.text: What exactly is reborn in Buddhist teachings?

annotations.text: Chanting Book p. 37
"What is the mind of an Arahant like?" ‚Äì "Only compassion"|Ajahn MahƒÅ Boowa

excerpts.text: I know that everything changes, and the only thing we can do is accept or be fine with that. But then you have a lot of resistance to acceptance. What can we do with that resistance?

annotations.text: So often Ajahn Chah would respond with the advice, |Just be patient.|

excerpts.text: When that flower is new, if we're aware of its impermanence and we accept that and we know that it's coming, is there any reason not to love the flower, appreciate its beauty, and accept it as a blessing?

annotations.text: A group of experienced Western Buddists ask Ajahn Chah about Right View. He replies, |Right View is knowing that this cup is broken.|

excerpts.text: Have you ever regretted choosing the monastic life? Has your mother ever thought you made a wrong choice?

annotations.text: on leadership.
You can't lead just by telling people what to do and they are going to obey. Forget it!
Everybody else is a mirror for oneself if one is willing to learn in teaching or leading others.

excerpts.text: What makes you keep on moving?
What would be your advice when young monks are wavering in their decsion?

annotations.text: Recurrent refrain in the Suttas: "I know you, MƒÅra," e. g. SN 4.1, SN 4.5.

excerpts.text: Going to Thailand‚Äîwas it a divine plan or was it your own wish? Is enlightenment a path or a destination?

annotations.text: None of the above.

excerpts.text: At the San Francisco Zen Center, they chant the Heart Sutra daily: 'No path, no knowledge, no attainment.' Could you help me understand the paths we're talking about here and Zen no-path?

annotations.text: [The Heart of Prajna Paramita Sutra](CTTB Chanting Book p. 44)
VijjƒÅcara·πáa-sampanno in the [Morning Chanting](Chanting Book p. 4).
Right view is knowing that this is a broken glass.|Ajahn Chah

excerpts.text: Can building a continuous narrative regarding impermanence hinder the perception of beauty?

annotations.text: It's not about finding a perfect position that you can be in. What you're doing is finding a place of balance that you're not shaken by anything.

excerpts.text: From the Christian perspective, I understand we get knowledge or wisdom from God, but it is through our human effort that we get a taste of the wisdom. You mentioned [neither] moving backward, forward, or being still. In Zen meditation, they taught being present. Is this grace or effort?

annotations.text: SN 1.1
To me it's much more faith that surrenders, that relinquishes, that's willing to let go.
Suffering and being stuck in sa·πÉsƒÅra and in the world is just a bad habit.

excerpts.text: Where can I find the effort and patience to transcend resistance? How can we balance effort and effortlessness?

annotations.text: Did you come here to die?|Ajahn Chah's greeting to newcomers.
If you really understood refuge in Buddha, Dhamma, and Sa·πÖgha, there wouldn't be a time when you bowed without bursting into tears of gratitude and devotion.

excerpts.text: Krishnamurti spoke of 'effortless effort.' Can you make sense of this?

annotations.text: Samma means right in tune.

excerpts.text: How can we have a renunciant life outside the monastery?
When I hear "renunciation," I have the feeling that I'm losing something.

annotations.text: What renunciation gives is inexhaustible strength of simplicity.|Martin Heidegger

excerpts.text: What is the translation of sabba·πÉ dukkha·πÉ? The way you translate it seems psychological. In Sanskrit, dukkha·πÉ means out of the cosmic flow of Dhamma. But perhaps dukkha·πÉ is best left untranslated. If untranslated, does dukkha·πÉ mean the same thing in Buddhism and Advaita Vedanta?

annotations.text: Ancient etymology of dukkha: du = bad, unwanted, unpleasant, uncomfotable, not easy; kha = where the alex fits into the wheel.
SN 22.22: Dhammacakkappavattanasutta ([Chanting Book translation](Chanting Book V2 p. 2))

NibbƒÅna is the reality of non-grasping.|Ajahn Chah

excerpts.text: Is the desire to become fearless a cause of suffering? Is wearing a different kind of clothes also I-making?

annotations.text: I saw many people show up [at Wat Pah Pong] with their list of what they thought a perfect teacher should be....and they would leave.

Chah2001.title: Remembering Ajahn Chah Weekend
Chah2001.description: On April 28-29, 2001, over 200 people gathered in Portola Valley to honor the life and teachings of Ajahn Chah. Senior monastic disciples, former monks and nuns, and people who briefly encountered Ajahn Chah recollect their experiences of this great teacher.

SRD2010.title: Recollections of Ajahn Chah
SRD2010.subtitle: His Life and Teachings
SRD2010.description: During this daylong retreat, Ajahn Pasanno shares teachings and memories of his beloved teacher, Ajahn Chah. By the time of his passing in 1992, Ajahn Chah had become one of the most highly revered Buddhist meditation masters in Thailand. The readings come from a draft version of Ajahn Jayasaro's biography of Ajahn Chah that was published as [Stillness Flowing](Stillness Flowing) in 2018.

SRD2011.title: Tudong Stories at Spirit Rock
SRD2011.description: Ajahn Pasanno offers stories of tudong (wandering pilgrimage) at a daylong event at Spirit Rock Meditation Center

UD2012-4.title: The Gradual Training
UD2012-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno and Ajahn Yatiko describe the Buddha's progressive teaching, which begins by encouraging generosity and virtue and goes on to describe the joys of heaven, the drawbacks in sensuality, the benefits of renunciation, and the Four Noble Truths.

UD2013-1.title: Right Livelihood
UD2013-1.description: Ajahn Pasanno reads from P. A. Payutto‚Äôs _Buddhist Economics_ and _A Constitution for Living_ and answers questions related to the topic of Right Livelihood.

SRD2013.title: The Whole of the Path: The Fruits of Spiritual Friendship

TG2013.title: Abhayagiri Monastic Retreat 2013
TG2013.subtitle: Brightening the Mind
TG2013.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

WR2014.title: Abhayagiri 2014 Winter Retreat
WR2014.subtitle: Our Roots in the Thai Forest Tradition
WR2014.description: The Abhayagiri Community take turns reading from translations of the Thai Forest masters. Ajahn Pasanno answers many questions following the readings.

UD2014-1.title: Death and Dying
UD2014-1.description: Sutta readings, reflections, personal stories, and questions about dying, death, and grief.

UD2014-2.title: Thai Forest Tradition
UD2014-2.description: Stories and readings about the origins and characteristics of the Thai Forest tradion.

UD2014-3.title: Mindfulness of Breathing
UD2014-3.description: Ajahn Pasanno describes mindfulness of breathing as a method to firmly establish the mind and develop insight.

DRBU2014.title: Questions and Answers with Dharma Realm Buddhist University
DRBU2014.description: A small group from the Dharma Realm Buddhist University (DRBU) located at the City of Ten Thousand Buddhas (CTTB) spent the morning at Abhayagiri. The group included two bhikkshunis as well as a number of resident volunteers at the CTTB. The students are in DRBU‚Äôs Masters of Arts in Buddhist Classics program. This semester the students have been reading various spiritual biographies including the biographies of the Thai Forest masters Ajahn Mun, Ajahn Tate and Ajahn Lee Dhammadharo. The audio is from their question and answer session with Ajahn Pasanno.

TG2014.title: 2014 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat
TG2014.subtitle: ‚ÄúJust Right‚Äù Practice
TG2014.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

WR2015.title: Abhayagiri 2015 Winter Retreat
WR2015.subtitle: The Four Foundations of Mindfulness

The structure often follows  _Right Mindfulness_ by Ajahn ·π¨hƒÅnissaro. There are noteworth [slideshows](#WR2015_S07) illustrating the 32 parts of the body.

UD2015-2.title: The Middle Way of Not-Self

UD2015-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno explains jhƒÅna as a fundamental clarity and stillness that the mind can experience.

TG2015.title: 2015 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat

TG2016.title: Thanksgiving Retreat 2016

TG2016.description: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

UD2017-2.title: Two Kinds of Thought and the Removal of Distracting Thoughts

UD2018-1.title: The New Ajahn Chah Biography

He focuses on the chapter ‚Äú[Out of Compassion](Stillness Flowing p. 581)‚Äù which describes Ajahn Chah's teachings to the lay community.

Path2019.title: The Path of Practice
Path2019.description: A weekend retreat lead by Ajahn Pasanno at the Victoria Insight Meditation Society in June 2019.

UD2019-4.title: Love, Attachment, and Friendship
UD2019-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno, Ajahn Karu·πáadhammo, and Ajahn √ëƒÅ·πáiko reflect on love, attachment, and friendship while reading from [On Love]().

UD2019-5.title: Developing Skill in Reflective Meditation
UD2019-5.description: Luang Por Pasanno, Ajahn Karunadhammo and Ajahn Nyaniko lead an exploration of the Buddha‚Äôs teachings on bringing a specific theme into the mind for reflection during meditation, including choosing and developing fruitful themes and the benefits of this skill.

Stanford2020.title: Stanford Community Dhamma Discussion
Stanford2020.subtitle: Reflections on the Path
Stanford2020.description: Ajahn Pasanno offers a live stream Dhamma talk and Q&A for the Buddhist Community at Stanford (BCAS).

UD2020.title: Living in a Changing Society
UD2020.subtitle: Dealing with Fear, Stress, and Worry and Cultivating Kindness, Patient Endurance, and Harmony

UD2021-1.title: Honoring the Buddha: The MahƒÅparinibbƒÅna Sutta
UD2021-1.description: Under the umbrella theme of ‚ÄúDevotion & Ritual,‚Äù the first UpƒÅsika Day of 2021 was on the topic of Honoring the Buddha: The MahƒÅparinibbƒÅna Sutta, DN 16.

Manijeh2021.title: Tea Time Q&A with Ajahn Pasanno
Manijeh2021.description: Manijeh Motaghy facilitates a question and answer session on Zoom with Venerable Ajahn Pasanno regarding how to use the Buddha‚Äôs teachings to relieve the stress of life.

Anniversary2021.title: Abhayagiri 25th Anniversary Retreat
Anniversary2021.subtitle: Nine Days of Dhamma
Anniversary2021.description: In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, the senior monks of Abhayagiri Monastery offered a nine-day hybrid retreat to celebrate its 25th anniversary. Only the two Q&A sessions hosted by Ajahn Pasanno are currently included in the Archive.

Kathina2021.title: Abhayagiri Ka·π≠hina 2021
Kathina2021.description: Abhayagiri Monastery spread the 2021 Ka·π≠hina festival over a period of seven days to accommodate the necessities of the pandemic. Question and answers were recorded on days two and four.

Podcast2023.title: Following the Path of a Forest Monk
Podcast2023.subtitle: A Treasure Mountain podcast
Podcast2023.description: Sol Hanna interviews Ajahn Pasanno about his life as a monk for the [Treasure Mountain Podcast](https://treasuremountain.stream/).

Madison2023.title: Madison Insight Retreat 2023
Madison2023.description: A weekend residential retreat organized by Madison Insight held at Pine Lake Retreat Center in rural Wisconsin.

Rishikesh2023.title: Interreligious Retreat-Seminar on Dhamma and Non-duality
Rishikesh2023.description: Swami Atmananda invited Ajahn Pasanno to provide a TheravƒÅda perspective on an interfaith weekend retreat at Ajatananda Ashram in Rishikesh, India.

Quote.usageNotes: A quote from the teacher him/herself.

Indirect quote.form2: ++Quote:++ {prefix} ‚Äú{text}‚Äù{' ‚Äî ' if suffix else ''}{suffix}||{'.' if suffix else ''} Quoted by {teachers}.
Indirect quote.usageNotes: The teacher quoting someone else. If the person quoted is a teacher, they should get the first tag.

Reading.usageNotes: {teachers} should be the author(s) of the book. Use a Read by annotation to indicate who does the reading. If the book appears in the list of references, {teachers} will be set and " by {teachers}" inserted automatically. If not, plug both in manually along with the hyperlink if relevant.

Comment.form1: ++Comment{s}++|| by {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text else " " + text}

Discussion.form1: ++Discussion{s}++|| led by {teachers}||{colon}{"." if not text else " " + text}

Summary.usageNotes: Used for session excerpts; can be blank. If the session excerpt has a list of items (e. g. readings), the items should be annotations to a summary excerpt.

Read by.form1: {'Read by ' if text else ''}{text}{'.' if text else ''}||{'' if text else 'Read by ' + teachers + '.'}
Read by.usageNotes: If the reader is not a teacher, {teachers} should be empty and {text} specifies the name of the reader.

Translated by.form1: {'Translated by ' if text else ''}{text}{'.' if text else ''}||{'' if text else 'Translated by ' + teachers + '.'}

Asked by.form1: {'Asked by ' if text else ''}{text}{'.' if text else ''}||{'' if text else 'Asked by ' + teachers + '.'}

Fragment.usageNotes: A fragment annotation indicates that the next annotation and its sub-annotations should be duplicated in a separate except following the main excerpt. The Fragment annotation itself is rendered as an audio player to play that excerpt.

Thanksgiving Retreats.description: The Abhayagiri Monastic Thanksgiving retreat was traditionally an annual ten-day residential retreat held at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa, California during the week of Thanksgiving. After the Angela Center closed due to fire damage in 2017 and the COVID pandemic began in 2020, the location, date, duration, and format of this retreat have varied significantly. [More...](about:Event-series#thanksgiving-retreats)

Abhayagiri Winter Retreats.description: During the months of January, February, and March, the resident community of Abhayagiri Monastery ceases all non-essential work to practice meditation. There are usually Dhamma readings nearly every day, some of which end with questions and answers regarding the teachings. [More...](about:Event-series#abhayagiri-winter-retreats)

Spirit Rock Daylongs.description: Senior monks from Abhayagiri typically lead several daylong teaching events each year at Spirit Rock Meditation Center in Woodacre, California. [More...](about:Event-series#spirit-rock-daylongs)

UpƒÅsikƒÅ Days.description: Well-organized afternoon teaching sessions held at Abhayagiri Monastery attended by committed supporters. Themes are chosen in advance and touch upon formal meditation practice, devotional practice, sutta study, daily life practice, and social aspects of Dhamma practice. [More...](about:Event-series#upasika-days)

Retreats.description: Multi-day retreats held at venues around the world.

Q&ampA sessions.description: Single question and answer sessions with groups of visitors or online participants.

Other.description: Events that don't fit into any of the above categories.

Spirit Rock Meditation Center.address: 5000 Sir Francis Drake Blvd., PO Box 169, Woodacre, CA 94973
